text: Cant remember exactly what the standard version has vs it but it has stuff like viewing pandas data frames , coverage for testing, threading debugging and performance stuff. Maybe not worth it for a developer of my skill but yes, the debugging tools are much better. Im surprised you dont have it. I think its only a few quid a month. They have monthly rolling options so id recommend trying it for a month and then binning it if you dont think its worth it

text:
<@U01C12ZEADQ> sorry i passed out it was like 4:30 am my time and I stayed up too late playing FTL. Yeah, data.table is pretty much it's own thing so it's borderline unrelated. That said, i had done some base R before, and hadn't had any problems with gotchas or anything. There are often more examples online for pandas, though.

For data.table, at least, I feel like its less verbose but that hasn't come with gotchas to me. Sometimes I just have to learn weird little tricks that are in there to help do what I want, but ultimately it's always doing what it seems like it should. I will def stan for it and think it's genius, but I'm no real programmer.

The basic gist is, compared to pandas, it generally assumes you're working inside the scope of the data.frame you're dealing with, and is really into powerful group bys with whatever statement. Everything is always df[subset stuff, stuff to do, group by stuff] and you can accomplish a ton with it.

So now, in pandas, I find myself writing:

newdf= df_name[['colname_tosum']].groupby(df_name['colname1'], df_name['colname2']).loc[df_name['colname3'] > 4].sum()

or something like that, where in data.table in R it would be.

newdf = df_name[colname3 > 4 , sum(colname_tosum), groupby = list(colname1, colname2)]

or just (the groupby is optional):

newdf = df_name[colname3 > 4 , sum(colname_tosum),  list(colname1, colname2)]

or could just calculate that new column in the same data.frame:

df_name[colname3 > 4 , newcol := sum(colname_tosum), list(colname1, colname2)]

it's probably a bit of what you're used to, and in this case the pandas line isn't that long, but it takes me forever to read that pandas line and figure out what's going on. On the other hand, I think if you are practiced in pandas, you don't default to group by etc. so much to solve your problems the way I do. Also, you might use way shorter df_names, i'm in the habit of writing long descriptive names because i usually in data.table write 'em just once per line. Anyhoo, that's my shpeal.

sorry i passed out it was like 4:30 am my time and I stayed up too late playing FTL. Yeah, data.table is pretty much it's own thing so it's borderline unrelated. That said, i had done some base R before, and hadn't had any problems with gotchas or anything. There are often more examples online for pandas, though.

For data.table, at least, I feel like its less verbose but that hasn't come with gotchas to me. Sometimes I just have to learn weird little tricks that are in there to help do what I want, but ultimately it's always doing what it seems like it should. I will def stan for it and think it's genius, but I'm no real programmer.

The basic gist is, compared to pandas, it generally assumes you're working inside the scope of the data.frame you're dealing with, and is really into powerful group bys with whatever statement. Everything is always df[subset stuff, stuff to do, group by stuff] and you can accomplish a ton with it.

So now, in pandas, I find myself writing:

newdf= df_name[['colname_tosum']].groupby(df_name['colname1'], df_name['colname2']).loc[df_name['colname3'] > 4].sum()

or something like that, where in data.table in R it would be.

newdf = df_name[colname3 > 4 , sum(colname_tosum), groupby = list(colname1, colname2)]

or just (the groupby is optional):

newdf = df_name[colname3 > 4 , sum(colname_tosum),  list(colname1, colname2)]

or could just calculate that new column in the same data.frame:

df_name[colname3 > 4 , newcol := sum(colname_tosum), list(colname1, colname2)]

it's probably a bit of what you're used to, and in this case the pandas line isn't that long, but it takes me forever to read that pandas line and figure out what's going on. On the other hand, I think if you are practiced in pandas, you don't default to group by etc. so much to solve your problems the way I do. Also, you might use way shorter df_names, i'm in the habit of writing long descriptive names because i usually in data.table write 'em just once per line. Anyhoo, that's my shpeal.
